abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was highly
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and institutional
            development impacts were substantial. The main lessons are
            addressed as follows. The importance of institutional
            building is largely emphasized by the transformation of the
            Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure (MTI), attributable
            to targeted technical assistance, training and studies, as
            well as to the integration of the project unit within the
            Ministry itself, staff continuity, and sustained involvement
            by the Bank, in coordination with other donors. Nonetheless,
            as dependable as the funding for the road maintenance fund
            (RMF) has been thus far, there is a long-term sustainability
            risk, derived from current reliance on budgetary financing.
            Hence, with the passing of the RMF Law, an agreement by the
            International Development Association (IDA) is recommended,
            for a Government time bound program, to ensure automatic
            funding of the RMF. Conversely, the cost effective, and
            sustainable methods of maintaining the road network in a
            resource constrained environment, engendered additional
            benefits: increased roads security; employment generation;
            and, the ability to provide assistance to flood stricken
            victims following the damages of Hurricane Mitch.
            Furthermore, this need for flexibility in disaster prone
            areas, facilitated the Bank's reallocation of funds, in
            the Government's efforts for financing remedial works.
            And, despite procurement delays caused by lack of
            familiarity with procurement procedures, it is clear that
            road construction would have been further delayed, had the
            task team not undertaken pre-qualification at the stage of
            project cycle.
